ALLEGATION:
Foster Parent A has a history of children services and licensing investigations
regarding poor home conditions. On 5/2/2022, Foster Parent A’s home was
observed to have unsuitable conditions for a foster home: including animal feces and
food on the floor, urine odor throughout, missing ceiling tiles and a broken door; as
well as flies and dirty dishes in the kitchen, and clothes piled up. There is a concern
the agency was aware of these foster home concerns and had not appropriately
addressed them.
INVESTIGATION:
On 5/11/2022 I reviewed the complaint; and on 5/12/2022 I spoke with the
complainant by telephone.

Complainant
During my 5/12/2022 telephone interview with the Complainant, the Complainant
provided a history on how she and the department came to have contact with Foster
Parent A’s home. The Complainant reported that Administrator 0 reached out to
District Manager/Deputy Director X related to concerns with Foster Parent A’s home;
and the agency’s licensing department looking to do revocation of the foster home’s
license. While the department was exploring the matter, District Manager/Deputy
Director X recalled that Child B had been placed in Foster Parent A’s home and
Child B was replaced because it was determined the home was not appropriate for
him. This realization led the department to check Child C’s (who remains placed in
Foster Home A) and the foster home’s files. They saw that there were minimum
social work contacts listed; and what was there was not addressing conditions of the
home. The department questioned, that if this home was not appropriate for Child B,
how could it be for Child C, especially given the fact the department was paying a
high difficulty of care rate to Foster Parent A for Child C’s care. Additionally, there
were some rejected and unrejected complaints which had come in related to the
foster home. All those things, coupled with the agency’s own concerns about the
home lead District Manager/Deputy Director X to ask the Complainant and the POS
(Purchase of Service) Monitor to make a safety check to verify Child C’s well-being
and Foster Parent A’s home condition. District Manager/Deputy Director X informed
Administrator 0 the department was going out to the foster home.
The Complainant reported, she and the POS Monitor made a visit to Foster Parent
A’s home at 5:00pm on 5/2/2022. During the home visit, upon entry into the home,
there was a strong urine odor and many flies flying throughout the home. The floor
was sticky. Bedrooms were cluttered. The kitchen had an abundant food, however,
there were dirty dishes piled up in the sink and the counter space. There were
multiple flies in the kitchen. There was open cat and dog food on the kitchen floor, as
well as the litter box. The door to the basement was broken and would not open all
the way. In the basement there were missing ceiling tiles, dog feces, and a urine
odor. There were clothes piled up in the basement to where one could not walk
freely around. The Complainant reported the issue of a poor, unsuitable home
condition has been a recurring situation for Foster Parent A. The Complainant
reported Spectrum licensed this home and should have had an idea of the foster
home’s conditions; and that the foster home is in violation R400.9301, R400.9307;
and the agency of its contract with the department. Additionally, that the agency
should have been more active and involved related to Foster Parent A’s
inappropriate home conditions, and the safety it posed to Child C. Especially, since
there was a 12/14/2021 social work contact entered by a prior agency’s worker, that
spoke to the foster home’s kitchen floor being sticky, flies, and there being a urine
odor in the home.
The Complainant reported a meeting was held with Spectrum via TEAMs on
5/10/2022 related to this complaint matter. At that time Spectrum reported they had
a foster care worker (FCW) to contact Foster Parent A. The worker reportedly was to
ask Foster Parent A to clean up, but the worker did not go out to the home until

5/11/2022. Spectrum also reported that they would conduct weekly unannounced
home visits to see if Foster Parent A’s home conditions have improved. Additionally,
Spectrum planned to do a placement stability Team Decision Meeting (TDM) referral
related to a placement change for Child C. The agency had a Family Team Meeting
(FTM) with Foster Parent A, and but did not invite the department.
On 5/19/2022 I interviewed Administrator/Division Director 1, Program Supervisor 2
and Director of Administrative Operations 3, onsite. All three-agency staff denied
awareness of the condition of Foster Parent A ‘s home condition, or that Child B was
removed from the foster home due it being inappropriate.
Administrator/Division Director 1
Administrator/Division Director (ADD) 1 admitted Foster Parent A has had a number
of complaints about her home and its upkeep, but Foster Parent A always corrected
the conditions. ADD 1 denied being aware of the multitude of inappropriate housing
issues for Foster Parent A until this complaint. She reported Last Foster Care
Worker 7 (who had Child C’s case from November 2021 until March 2022); Past
Foster Worker (FCW) 6(who recently resigned/had Child C’s case from 3/11/22-
5/16/22); the most recent supervisor, Supervisor 8 (who resigned 4/29/2022); nor
Past Foster Care Supervisor (PFCS) 5(who carried Child C’s case prior to FCW 6)
reported any such concerns to her. She denied seeing a 12/2021 social contact
indicating documentation of a sticky floor, flies, and the home smelling of urine. She
stated that information much have not been taken to their licensing department. She
reported she did not know, because no one was reporting what was going on in
Foster Parent A’s home. She did not know why the staff would not have been
reported this information. She reported the agency has had a major problem with
staff turnover; and she attributed this as a part of the problem.
ADD 1 reported Foster Parent A has also had some struggles around taking on too
much and the agency has worked with her. The agency offered Foster Parent A
support, by way of offering respite, and connecting her with Children Center around
working with traumatized children. The agency also reduced Foster Parent A’s
license capacity (Foster Parent A used to be licensed as a group home), to better
enable her ability to care for Child C. ADD 1 denied Foster Parent A not being able
to meet, the previous child, Child B’s need or DHHS asking for Child B’s removal
from Foster Parent A’s home due to the home being inappropriate. ADD 1 said
Foster Parent A requested Child B’s removal, because Foster Parent A reported
Foster Parent A could no longer handle Child B’s behaviors. A TDM was held and
there was a whole plan around his removal in latter February or early March of 2022.
Child B’s POS monitor was involved the process. As for Child C, ADD 1 did not
express concern that his needs are not being met in the foster home. She reported
Child C’s remains in the home, and they are not looking to replace him at this time.
Child C has numerous special needs and there are no known placement prospects
for him yet.

Program Supervisor 2
Program Supervisor 2 reported she is temporarily covering Child C’s case until a
worker is hired. In terms of foster care workers not knowing about the conditions of
the foster home, Program Supervisor 2 reported Foster Parent A had COVID at one
time and the workers may have completed safety visits whereby they would not have
toured the foster home. She also denies anyone reporting these serious foster home
conditions to her.
As for Child B’s removal from the foster home, she said DHHS was aware of Child
B’s issues because DHHS teamed up with the agency around supervision when
Child B was hospitalized.
Director of Administrative Operations 3
As previously stated, Director of Administrative Operations (DAO) 3 was interviewed
by me in person on 5/19/2022. Email correspondences were also had with her as
documented in the mythology section of this report. DAO 3 reported stepping in to
assist the agency’s foster care/licensing department in late February or early March
of this year. She has not yet completed licensing training as the agency hopes to fill
the licensing supervisor position quickly; and much of the supervisory tasks have
been completed by Administrator 0 and ADD 1 who both have completed the
training. However, because of the hiring crisis, DAO 3 was enrolling in supervisor’s
foster care and licensing training on 6/22/2022.
DAO 3 reported Foster Parent A has been licensed with the agency for some time;
and it is known that historically, Foster Parent A is not the best housekeeper. DAO 3
said, what “DHHS discovered on 5/2/2022 was not known to us”. She reported that
since the last complaint the agency received on Foster Parent A’s home, something
must have occurred in/to the home. Such as Foster Parent A’s sewage backing up
and a pipe busting in the basement. DAO 3 reported, Foster Parent A had not
reported those things to the agency. DAO 3 was not sure why foster care workers
would not have noticed these issues. DAO 3 injected, that maybe a worker had,
given there was a prior complaint. She reported the urine smell in the home may
have been due to both Child B and Child C having enuresis. She reported
information like ADD 1 related to Foster Parent A’s pattern; which was that the
agency would notice an environmental concerns in the home; they would mention
the matter to Foster Parent A; and Foster Parent A would fix the matter. Foster
Parent A had a hard time maintaining the standard for a long period of time. DAO 3
reported as of 5/13/2022 all of Foster Parent A’s home issues have been rectified.
The pipe and sewage are fixed, the bedrooms are not cluttered, files are gone, and
the floors are clean. The basement where Foster Parent A’s adopted adult children
lives is also clean.
DAO 3 admitted the agency has had a few meetings to discuss, Foster Parent A’s
systemic history; to explore what support or assistance and resources could be
offered Foster Parent A. At times Foster Parent A was accepting and wanted the
assistance; and many times, Foster Parent A wanted to do things on her own. DAO

3 reported, prior to DHHS’s 5/2/2022 visit, the agency was planning to discuss with
Foster Parent A that perhaps it was time to retire her license. In the interim, the
agency wanted to do more preparation around Child C’s replacement first. The
agency did not want a situation similar to Child B’s to occur. Child B was replaced
from Foster Parent A’s after the foster parent put in a 30-day notice. Child B went to
a relative but returned due to the relative inability of to care for him. Child B
deteriorated after coming back to Foster Parent A’s home; and then was
hospitalized. The agency does not want that same faith for Child C; and is trying to
do more preparation and planning for his replacement from Foster Parent A’s home.
Past Licensing Supervisor 4
On 6/14/2022 I interviewed Past Licensing Supervisor (PLS) 4 by telephone. PLS 4
recalled Foster Parent A and special issues related to the foster parent’s home and
licensure. She reported Foster Parent A was always getting a specialized rate for
the children Foster Parent A’s cared for, inclusive of, Child B, and Child C, but
Foster Parent A did not always provide all that the children needed developmentally
and or supervisory wise. She said the agency had knowledge of this and of Child
C’s needs for extra supervision greater than what Foster Parent A was providing.
She reported an example of such by indicating staff had observed Child C beating
up on Foster Parent A in the office. She reported the agency gave the appearance of
providing support to Foster Parent A, but they did not fully follow through. PLS 4
reported speaking out about these concerns when she was on staff at the agency.
This included recommending a reduction in Foster Parent A’s license, when Foster
Parent A was licensed as a group home/had five special needs children placed in
the home. She reported she also advised foster care workers of what to look for
during foster home visits. Additionally, that she recommended revocation of Foster
Parent A’s license in 2021.
PLS reported Foster Parent A has had a number of poor housekeeping complaints
in the past. Additionally, that the home has smelled of urine and that the dogs/pets
were also peeing the floor. She said, Foster Parent A does well when workers give
Foster Parent A the lists of noncompliance to fix. Foster Parent A follows up and
takes care of the noncompliance. Additionally, that as long as Foster Parent A
knows “you are watching her, she will spruce things up” but it always ends back up
in a deplorable situation. PLS believed Foster Parent A’s faulted home conditions
came about due to a lack of close supervision and monitoring. She indicated Foster
Parent A overextends herself, was overwhelmed with Child B and Child C. She said
the agency has always known of these housing issues. She denied knowledge of
Foster Parent A’s home to have dog feces on the floor or flies.
Prior Foster Care Supervisor 5
On 6/15/2022, I interviewed Prior Foster Care Supervisor (PFS)5 by telephone. PFS
5 reported leaving the agency on 4/10/2022. She admitted being the prior supervisor
and to carrying case responsibility for the foster children’s cases, at times. She
recalled Foster Parent A having housekeeping concerns when the agency’s
licensing department completed Foster Parent A’s annual home inspection in

November or December of 2021. She said the licensing staff gave Foster Parent A a
list of concern to address. PFS 5 also reported historical maintenance issues for the
foster home. She said the home was never in perfect condition; licensing was
addressing the concerns, and possibly issuing a corrective action plan. She reported
making a home visit to Foster Parent A’s foster home in November and December of
2021, and January and February of 2022. During each of those reported home visits,
she noticed that the home smelled of urine. She said she knew Child B was getting
up in the middle of the night and peeing in the closet; and would also hide his
soaked clothes under his mattress. Child C also had bet wetting issues. She said
the house was also cluttered but not unsafe. She said, the pet litter box was out by
the bathroom, but there was no pet waste on the floor. She said Child B would also
put food under his bed, and the floor might be sticky. PFS 5 said she instructed
Foster Parent A to clean up. She said in November or December of 2021 Foster
Parent A sent her pictures showing Foster Parent A had completed a deep cleaning
of the wooden floors, closet; and also sent pictures of the bedroom. PFS 5 did not
report whether some type of safety plan was done to address Child B and Child C’s
ongoing enuresis issues. She said her last visit to the foster home was on 3/16/2022
and the home was not as described in the complaint.
PFS 5 reported concerns the agency had with Foster Parent A were due to Foster
Parent A feeling stressed over caring for Child B, which PFS 5 also said lead to
replacement efforts for Child B. PFS also admitted the agency explored the matter
of Foster Parent A not having foster children. This exploration was had by her, ADD
1, PLS 4, and the prior licensing worker, in November 2021. The outcome of that
discussion was that Foster Parent A was overwhelmed, and the agency would put in
supports, as well as, that Foster Parent A would explore getting community living
respite services for Child C. PFS 5 also admitted there was a period of time Foster
Parent A was in the hospital due to COVID and this was when extra services were
explored and provided to Foster Parent A. PFS 5, said, Foster Parent A’s adult
Adopted Son D was with Child B and Child C. She was going out every weekend to
check on the family. She was also taking food; and another supervisor transported
Child B to school. Adopted Son D, walked Child D home from school and a bus
transported Child C to and from school. PFS 5 said the placement was still
appropriate at that time.
Prior Foster Care Worker 6
On 6/15/2022, I interviewed prior Foster Care Worker (FCW) 6 by telephone. FCW 6
was the foster care specialist for Child C’s case from 4/19/2022- 5/16/2022. She
was aware of the complaint this special investigation relates to. She made an
unannounced foster home visit on 5/11/22 with Program Supervisor 2, after DHHS
disclosed information related to DHHS’s visit to Foster Parent A’s home on 5/2/2022.
FCW 6 addressed the housing concerns with Foster Parent A and put in a safety
plan. Foster Parent A said, Foster Parent A did not realize how bad the basement
living conditions were; that she was still recovering from COVID and had not venture
downstairs. Foster Parent A reported the flies in her home were due to a broken
pipe drain. Foster Parent A said the matter started out as a leaky pipe, built up, and

then the flies came. Foster Parent A reported she had different repair people out;
and fixed what was reported. Then one day there was a big gush of water, and
Foster Parent A realized the pipe had rusted out. On 5/12/2022, Foster Parent A
reported a person was coming out to repair the pipe.
FCW 6 admitted to observing sanitary issue with Foster Parent A’s home prior to
DHHS’s 5/2/2022 home visit. She made a foster home visit on 4/27/2022. At that
April 2022 visit, FCW 6 said the floor was sticky, there were flies in the house,
clothes were piled up on the couch. Foster Parent A reported, Foster Parent A was
doing laundry and FCW 3 accepted that for the clothing clutter. As for the dishes,
FCW 6 took it that Foster Parent A was behind on her housekeeping and was
overwhelmed. She admitted to seeing cat food about, but she did not see a cat or
dog. Nor did she ask the foster parent whether there were pets in home. Nor did
she go into the basement. She said she was a new worker and was not completely
abreast on what constituted poor and unsafe housing standards. She said she had
a conversation with Supervisor 9, about the 4/27/2022 foster home visit and
Supervisor 9 told her Foster Parent A was dealing with a lot. Supervisor 9 did not
address whether FCW 6 needed to do anything further. FCW 6 denied an
awareness of a meeting with Foster Parent A prior to this complaint related to Foster
Parent A’s poor housekeeping. She recalled an agency meeting related to Foster
Parent A’s interaction with Child C due to Child C’s special needs/Child C being a lot
to handle. FCW 6 said she was never advised that Foster Parent A required
assistance with housekeeping, only help related the behavioral needs of Child C.
Reviewed:
Foster Parent A MISACWIS provider record- I reviewed:
 Social work contact from 5/1/2021-6/30/2022 which showed nine
contacts, three (5/14/2021,5/26/2021 and 6/3/2021) were non-face- to-
face related to special evaluations by the licensing supervisor or
licensing worker at the time. The remaining contacts were contacts by
Child B’s adoption specialist, and one (10/26/2021) was a foster home
visit by that adoption worker. None of the contacts indicated a foster
home safety concern.
 Foster Parent A’s 11/8/2020- 11/7/2021 Foster home reevaluation
(DCWL 4004) completed 10/22/2021. The reevaluation indicated there
to be no changes in the appearance and cleanliness of the home since
the last evaluation; and that the home continued to be appropriate for
fostering. The reevaluation documented social work contacts with
Foster Parent A for 8/30/2021, 10/30/2021 and 10/14/2021.The latter
contact was for a home visit. These contacts are not listed in
MISACWIS.
 Three pending special evaluations for intakes on 10/6/2021,11/7/2021,
2/11/2022 and 4/15/2022. The 2/11/2022 intake included allegations
that Foster Parent A was hospitalized with COVID, leaving the foster
children home alone. Additionally, that Child B and Child C have been

urinating and defecating throughout the home. The home is in poor
condition and smell very badly.
 Child C’s MISACWIS case record (and viewed social work contacts for 5/1/2021-
5/30/2022) which showed:
 There were four separate workers (one of whom was Past Foster Care
Supervisors 5) during the time frame listed above.
 Spectrum foster home visit dates of 5/18/2021, 6/4/2021, 7/26/2021,
10/8/2021, 10/27/2021,12/14/2021, 12/21/2021, 1/19/2022, 2/28/2022,
3/16/2022, 4/27/2022, 5/2/2022(by DHHS) and 5/11/2022.
 Two of the Spectrum home visits (10/27/2021 & 5/11/2022) listed above,
as well, the 5/2/2022 DHHS visit, were unannounced foster home visits.
With the except of the 5/2/2022 DHHS foster home visit, and the agency’s
10/8/2021 12/14/2021, and 4/27/2022 foster home visits, a consistent
description of interaction within the home, what was observed or whether
there were any safety concern in the home, that observation of the child’s
bedroom occurred was not documented.
 The record did not show documentation of an August, September or
November 2021 foster home visit with Foster Child C and the foster
parent.
 The foster home visit documentations for 12/14/2021 and 4/27/2022
indicated concerns within the home.
 The 12/14/2021 visit indicated the “worker entered the home and
noticed what appeared to be a urine smell in the home. The house
also had a lot of flies, and the floor was sticky. Foster Parent A was
spraying the shelves with what appeared to be a bleach product.”
 The 4/27/2022 visit indicated the home had “a few flies in it and
some clutter, but other than that there were no safety concerns”
 These two-home visit documentations did not indicate whether or
not the concerns were discussed with Foster Parent A.
 A DHS-1105 for a FTM Activity report which indicated an FTM was held
on 5/9/2022, which showed FCW 6 and Supervisor 9 in attendance along
with Foster Parent A. During this FTM, Child A’s, development; family and
kinship relationships, mental health and well-being, and Foster Parent A’s
housing concerns from DHHS’s home visit were discussed. The
recommendation section of this DHS-1105 indicated it was recommended
that Foster Parent A clean up her house, as per DHHS requirements.
APPLICABLE RULE
R 400.12207 Staff responsibilities.
(3) An agency shall require that social service workers be
directly responsible for all of the following activities:
(a) Placing and supervising children in out-of-home care.
Social service workers shall work directly with the children,
their families, and other relevant individuals and be
primarily responsible for the development, implementation,

and review of service plans for the children and their
families.
(b)Assessing and certifying private family homes for
licensure and supervising the home
ANALYSIS: There is sufficient evidence to support that the agency knew
about the foster home’s very poor housing condition prior, as
recent as 4/27/2022 when the foster care worker observed
housing concerns like what the complaint indicated. The foster
care worker, the supervisor, nor a licensing staff addressed
those concerns at the time. Nor was there housing safety
planning with the foster parent in December 2021 when the
home was observed to be smelling of urine and having flies.
Additionally, the agency staff did not adequately assess the
home, or document consistent quality visits during foster home
visits. Nor did the agency complete foster home visits in August,
September or November 2021; and did not provide sufficient
foster home supervision or timely follow up on the 2/11/2022
complaint related to the alleged poor foster home conditions.
The agency’s lack of, oversight, timely intervention and direct
work with relevant individuals, likely contributed to the home
getting to the point it had on 5/2/2022.
Repeat Violation- 2022C0420002-October 2021,
2021C0420042- September 2021.
CONCLUSION: VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
ALLEGATION:
The agency has not been consistently documenting its contacts related to the foster
home and visits.
INVESTIGATION:
On 5/12/2022 I interviewed the Complainant by telephone. The Complainant
reported, Spectrum has minimum social work contacts in MISACWIS related to Child
C’s case. The Complainant reported Spectrum’s administrators’ had a limited
response for those lack of contacts. The administrator reported it was due to worker
turnover; and that the workers who the contacts are no longer with the agency.
ADD 1 was interviewed onsite on 5/19/2022. She reported worker turnover
contributed to inconsistent social work contact documentation.
Reviewed:
MISACWIS case record for Foster Parent A and Child C as referenced earlier in this
report.

 Foster Parent A’s record showed:
 No documentation of a in person contact related to the 2/11/2022 and
4/15/2022 special evaluation intake complaints.
 The foster parent’s reevaluation documented social work contacts with
Foster Parent A for 8/30/2021, 10/30/2021 and 10/14/2021(this one is
listed as a home visit). These three contacts are not listed in MISACWIS.
 Child C’s record showed:
 Various social work contacts did not contain information required related
to documenting a quality visits.
 Various contacts were not entered in MISACWIC within the five-business

listed below in MISACWIS within five business days of the

contacts.
Quality visit:
A quality visit is defined as one in which the caseworker:

• Assesses each child’s educational, medical, dental, mental
health and other needs and takes appropriate action or offers
services in response to the identified needs of each child.
Required discussion:

The caseworker must discuss the following topics monthly with
the child's caregiver and document the information provided by
the caregiver in the appropriate work area in MiSACWIS. This

treatment, follow-up care, and progress updates.
• Child behaviors, concerns, developmental milestones.

provided.

extraordinary care required of the caregiver; see FOM 903-03,
Payments for Foster Family Care.
• Child's adjustment to the caregiver's family.
